subjects.name: Python Complete Course
subjects.description: Master Python from basics to advanced with detailed examples and real-world projects

topics.title: Introduction to Python
topics.description: Understanding Python fundamentals, installation, and your first program

contents.title: What is Python?
contents.content:
Python is a high-level, interpreted, general-purpose programming language created by Guido van Rossum in 1991.

Key Features:
‚Ä¢ Easy to Learn: Simple, readable syntax
‚Ä¢ Interpreted: No compilation needed
‚Ä¢ Dynamically Typed: No need to declare variable types
‚Ä¢ Object-Oriented: Supports OOP concepts
‚Ä¢ Extensive Libraries: Rich standard library
‚Ä¢ Cross-Platform: Works on Windows, Mac, Linux
‚Ä¢ Free and Open Source: No licensing costs

Why Python is Popular:
‚Ä¢ Used by Google, Netflix, Instagram, NASA
‚Ä¢ #1 language for Data Science and AI
‚Ä¢ Great for beginners and experts
‚Ä¢ Huge community support
‚Ä¢ Versatile - web, data, automation, etc.

Python Applications:
‚Ä¢ Web Development (Django, Flask)
‚Ä¢ Data Science & Machine Learning
‚Ä¢ Automation & Scripting
‚Ä¢ Game Development
‚Ä¢ Desktop Applications
‚Ä¢ Scientific Computing
‚Ä¢ IoT and Robotics

contents.title: Python vs Other Languages
contents.content:
Python vs JavaScript:
‚Ä¢ Python: General-purpose, backend-focused
‚Ä¢ JavaScript: Web-focused, frontend & backend
‚Ä¢ Python: Easier syntax for beginners
‚Ä¢ JavaScript: Essential for web development

Python vs Java:
‚Ä¢ Python: Dynamically typed, less verbose
‚Ä¢ Java: Statically typed, more verbose
‚Ä¢ Python: Faster development
‚Ä¢ Java: Better performance for large apps

Python vs C++:
‚Ä¢ Python: High-level, slower execution
‚Ä¢ C++: Low-level, faster execution
‚Ä¢ Python: Easier to learn and write
‚Ä¢ C++: More control over system resources

Python Versions:
‚Ä¢ Python 2.x: Legacy (deprecated)
‚Ä¢ Python 3.x: Current (use this!)
‚Ä¢ Latest: Python 3.12 (as of 2024)
‚Ä¢ Always use Python 3.x for new projects

contents.title: Installing Python
contents.content:
Installation Steps:

Windows:
1. Visit python.org
2. Download Python 3.x installer
3. Run installer
4. Check 'Add Python to PATH'
5. Click 'Install Now'
6. Verify: Open CMD, type 'python --version'

Mac:
1. Python 2.x comes pre-installed
2. Install Python 3 from python.org
3. Or use Homebrew: brew install python3
4. Verify: Terminal, type 'python3 --version'

Linux (Ubuntu/Debian):
1. Usually pre-installed
2. Update: sudo apt update
3. Install: sudo apt install python3
4. Verify: python3 --version

IDEs and Editors:
‚Ä¢ PyCharm (Professional IDE)
‚Ä¢ VS Code (Lightweight, popular)
‚Ä¢ Jupyter Notebook (Data Science)
‚Ä¢ IDLE (Comes with Python)
‚Ä¢ Sublime Text, Atom (Text editors)

contents.title: Your First Python Program
contents.content:
# This is a comment in Python
# Comments start with # symbol

# Print to console
print('Hello, World!')
print('Welcome to Python Programming!')

# Print multiple items
print('Python', 'is', 'awesome!')

# Print with separator
print('Apple', 'Banana', 'Mango', sep=', ')

# Print numbers
print(10)
print(3.14)
print(2 + 3)  # Output: 5

# Print without newline
print('Hello', end=' ')
print('World')  # Output: Hello World

# Multi-line strings
print('''
This is a
multi-line
string
''')

# Escape characters
print('Hello\nWorld')  # \n = newline
print('Hello\tWorld')  # \t = tab
print('She said, "Python is great!"')  # Quotes inside string

examples.title: Interactive Python Shell
examples.code:
# Open terminal/command prompt
# Type: python3 (or python)
# You'll see: >>>

>>> print('Hello')
Hello

>>> 2 + 2
4

>>> name = 'Raj'
>>> print(f'My name is {name}')
My name is Raj

# Exit: type exit() or Ctrl+D
examples.explanation: Python interactive shell (REPL) lets you test code immediately. Great for learning and quick experiments.

examples.title: Running Python Files
examples.code:
# Create a file: hello.py
# Add this code:

print('Hello from Python file!')
name = input('Enter your name: ')
print(f'Welcome, {name}!')

# Run in terminal:
# python3 hello.py
# or
# python hello.py
examples.explanation: Save Python code in .py files and run them from terminal. This is how you create Python programs.

examples.title: Python Syntax Rules
examples.code:
# Python uses INDENTATION (spaces/tabs)
# No curly braces like JavaScript/Java

# Correct indentation
if True:
    print('This is indented')  # 4 spaces
    print('Same level')

# Wrong indentation causes error
# if True:
# print('Error!')  # IndentationError

# Use 4 spaces (recommended)
# Don't mix tabs and spaces

# Case sensitive
name = 'Raj'
Name = 'Priya'  # Different variable
print(name)  # Raj
print(Name)  # Priya
examples.explanation: Python uses indentation to define code blocks. Always use 4 spaces for indentation. Python is case-sensitive.

examples.title: Getting User Input
examples.code:
# input() function gets user input as string
name = input('Enter your name: ')
print('Hello, ' + name + '!')

# Convert input to integer
age = int(input('Enter your age: '))
print(f'You are {age} years old')

# Convert input to float
price = float(input('Enter price: '))
print(f'Price: ‚Çπ{price}')

# Multiple inputs
name = input('Name: ')
age = input('Age: ')
city = input('City: ')
print(f'{name}, {age}, from {city}')
examples.explanation: input() function reads user input as a string. Use int() or float() to convert to numbers.

contents.title: Python Keywords and Identifiers
contents.content:
Python Keywords (Reserved Words):
You cannot use these as variable names:

and, as, assert, break, class, continue, def, del, elif, else, except, False, finally, for, from, global, if, import, in, is, lambda, None, nonlocal, not, or, pass, raise, return, True, try, while, with, yield

Identifier Rules:
‚Ä¢ Must start with letter (a-z, A-Z) or underscore (_)
‚Ä¢ Can contain letters, digits (0-9), underscore
‚Ä¢ Cannot start with digit
‚Ä¢ Case-sensitive (age and Age are different)
‚Ä¢ Cannot be a keyword

Naming Conventions:
‚Ä¢ Variables: lowercase_with_underscores
‚Ä¢ Constants: UPPERCASE_WITH_UNDERSCORES
‚Ä¢ Functions: lowercase_with_underscores
‚Ä¢ Classes: CapitalizedWords (PascalCase)
‚Ä¢ Private: _leading_underscore

Examples:
‚úÖ Valid: name, age, user_name, _private, name123
‚ùå Invalid: 123name, my-name, for, class
